_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and
documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To
accomplish this, POM Wonderful has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by
Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking
RMP-PSM related activities.

1.1 POM Wonderful, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that POM Wonderful has updated/developed their
unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and
maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold
quantities:

Process Name         Process Chemical               Process Quantity(lbs.)
Fresh Side           Anhydrous Ammonia              45,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to
prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals.
Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property
damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We
have:
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as

we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual
mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.

1.4 Five Year Accident History

1) 8/3/2009 - At approximately 11:45AM while a contractor employee was moving equipment with a forklift, a
1/2 purge valve on the condenser drain drop leg was impacted, breaking the nipple at the threads and
releasing liquid ammonia. The approximate leak area was 0.0367 sq. in. During the first 5 minutes of the
release the approximate pressure in the pipe was 135 psig. After 5 minutes, all necessary valves were isolated
and the pressure dropped to 10 psig. It took approximately 25 minutes for the release to stop once the valves
were isolated. Using Equation (3) in the Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration, it is
estimated that 850 lb of ammonia were released over a 30 minute period.

Further details about resolution and follow up actions are contained in Incident Investigation report 2009-01.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

POM Wonderful's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following
requirements:
California Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29 CFR §1910.38

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and
evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and
their Hazardous Materials Response Team.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

POM Wonderful has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public
safety. Nevertheless, POM Wonderful continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.
By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM
program. This has improved POM Wonderful's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and
contractors. I

water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas
ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to our high pressure receiver. Liquid separated from the suction
return gas in the main suction accumulator drains into liquid transfer vessels. Operation of a float switch
activated solenoid valve raises the pressure in the liquid transfer vessels to the point the liquid can be drained
into the high pressure receivers. Some of the coils (Anti-Room 2) are direct expansion coils. In those coils,
high pressure ammonia liquid is piped directly to each coil where it passes through a solenoid valve, a hand
expansion valve, and directly into the coil. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low
temperature & pressure gas which is returned directly to the main suction accumulator via the suction main.
The facility was originally called Met-West and then later changed to Paramount Fruit. In 2007, the name
changed to POM Wonderful. The facility was built more than 20 years ago. More recently the following projects
have occurred:
2004 - California Controlled Atmosphere added eight (8) new controlled atmosphere rooms
2006 - California Controlled Atmosphere added two (2) new high pressure receivers
2006 - California Controlled Atmosphere made modifications to the compressor oil cooling on the Fresh System
2007 - California Controlled Atmosphere added a screw compressor and condenser to the Juice System
2008 - California Controlled Atmosphere installed a complete computer control system on for the Juice System
2009 - California Controlled Atmosphere installed a compressor, condenser, and plate and frame heat exchanger on the Juice System
2010 - Ross & Sons installed a 500 hp screw compressor and ten (10) coils in the Fresh System

The systems contain numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or
pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to

a water
diffusion tank (Juice System and new C.A. Rooms) or atmosphere (Fresh System) if the pressure in the system
exceeds their set point. In addition, ammonia detectors are located in selected areas of the facility, and will shut
down equipment if ammonia is detected. Lastly, an emergency dump box contains switches and valves to turn
off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.

The ammonia system at our facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such
that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected. Therefore,
we are treating the each system as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous
ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as
evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

POM Wonderful has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release
scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event
of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders.

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the POM Wonderful facility is an integral part of the overall business and
operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and
efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential
danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active logbook of all
procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of
the outside refrigeration contractors that

well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors
protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

POM Wonderful operates a cold storage facility that performs activities related pomegranate storage and juice
production. The facility has two (2) ammonia systems (Fresh System and Juice System). The Fresh System
provides refrigerating capacity to seven cold rooms, two anti-rooms, a shipping area, the mechanical room, and
sixteen controlled atmosphere rooms. The rooms use a combination of bunker style coils and ceiling
suspended evaporator coils that contain chilled liquid ammonia. Some of the ceiling suspended coils operate
under flooded conditions and some under direct expansion. The Juice System provides refrigerating capacity to
a shell and tube heat exchanger, a plate and frame heat exchanger, the Tank Room, and the Blend Room. A
computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability.

The Fresh System operates as follows: high pressure liquid from our high pressure receivers is piped through
the king solenoid valve. From there it is piped to each flooded zone of refrigeration, where it passes through a
solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a low temperature & pressure accumulator vessel. From the
accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid
ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature & pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The
ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulator vessels through a suction return line to our main suction
accumulator in the engine room. From there, it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge
from the compressors is sent to our

n addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that POM Wonderful's management
team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

POM Wonderful has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program
requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.)
any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and
given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using
PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access
to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, POM Wonderful has also
entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.
For the future, POM Wonderful now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive
framework that guides safe action for POM Wonderful employees, but allows for feedback and continual
improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program POM Wonderful will continue to maintain overall plant worker
and public safety.
